text: Is quantum physics "fundamentally truly random" or just "indistinguishable from truly random given the current limits of our understanding"?

elements.text: Is quantum physics "fundamentally truly random" or just "indistinguishable from truly random given the current limits of our understanding"?

text: I'm not sure the distinction between those two things is as meaningful as you might be thinking, but sure, you could have a universe wide pseudorandom number generator selecting wavefunction branches. I wouldn't put money on that though

elements.text: I'm not sure the distinction between those two things is as meaningful as you might be thinking, but sure, you could have a universe wide pseudorandom number generator selecting wavefunction branches. I wouldn't put money on that though

text: also gets pretty tricky when relativity gets involved

elements.text: also gets pretty tricky when relativity gets involved

text: there are quite a few hidden variable theories that are compatible with what we know about quantum mechanics, it's just classical hidden variables which are impossible

elements.text: there are quite a few hidden variable theories that are compatible with what we know about quantum mechanics, it's just classical hidden variables which are impossible

text: Things get a bit dicey when one ventures beyond the known into the unknown-but-knowable territory and gazes into the unknowable.  I think humans have a somewhat arrogant tendency to think that our collective finite sets of neurons will be able to comprehend anything/everything one day.

elements.text: Things get a bit dicey when one ventures beyond the known into the unknown-but-knowable territory and gazes into the unknowable.  I think humans have a somewhat arrogant tendency to think that our collective finite sets of neurons will be able to comprehend anything/everything one day.
